channel.title: Project Cleanup issue
channel.description: I'm having problems with the Project cleanup source. I set it up with the Gui like every other server but nobody can connect and it cant register with the website, If I use another source it works fine but I really want to use the Project Cleanup source, help would be greatly appreciated! (I'm posting here because I think it is a general problem I'm having with set up, not the source itself)

item.title: Project Cleanup issue
item.dc:creator: @wintzer wintzer
item.description:
@wintzer wrote:

[quote=“Mr…x…, post:10, topic:403261”]Np.
But sorry, I think your .jar questions would be better off for someone else. I have never made a .jar file, I have just heard lots about it.

Mayb you should make a new post about that question ;)[/quote]

Alright, thanks again for all the help If I could rep I would right now

Read full topic

item.title: Project Cleanup issue
item.dc:creator: @wintzer wintzer
item.description:
@wintzer wrote:

[quote=“Mr…x…, post:8, topic:403261”]Yes, and have you looked at ric’s webclient tut?
Here it is below
http://www.moparisthebest.com/smf/index.php/topic,336494.0.html[/quote]

I Believe I have and atm I am not searching for a webclient as much as a way to jar and upload the client, so I’m not tossing around the whole folder, I have tried the method of jarring in this tut as well. Do I need anything besides the .jar like a premade cache?

EDIT: Client issue fixed! Thanks a lot!!!

Read full topic

item.title: Project Cleanup issue
item.dc:creator: @wintzer wintzer
item.description:
@wintzer wrote:

[quote=“Mr…x…, post:6, topic:403261”]Well for the client, go to Client.java. There should be three of the current ports and you must change them all.
Search for this

The line of code should look like this:

**** = your current port.
Once you find your port, and change it to what ever your server it set to, simply search for the rest of the ports and change them all… Compile done.[/quote]

So after your example I change these?

Because if not those are the only 3 codes with 5555 in them in the entire Client.java. Also any thought on my jarring issue?
EDIT: I have tried Jar.exe, JARmaker and also tried with cmd, same results.

Read full topic

item.title: Project Cleanup issue
item.dc:creator: @Mr_x1 Mr...x..
item.description:
@Mr_x1 wrote:

Well for the client, go to Client.java. There should be three of the current ports and you must change them all.
Search for this

The line of code should look like this:

**** = your current port.
Once you find your port, and change it to what ever your server it set to, simply search for the rest of the ports and change them all… Compile done.

//EDIT: Have you tried to use the jar.exe utility program from JDK?

Read full topic

item.title: Project Cleanup issue
item.dc:creator: @wintzer wintzer
item.description:
@wintzer wrote:

Mr...x..:

Ahaha, sweet, lets hope it works

One last problem Now my client wont connect and I’m thinking its the port again because it worked before when the server was 5555, problem is I cant find the config for ports in the client folder

EDIT: Thought I might as well ask- I wanted to turn my client folder into a .jar and also get it signed for a webclient, but I seem to be having an issue where the jar has errors downloading cache when run. Any ideas?

Read full topic

item.title: Project Cleanup issue
item.dc:creator: @wintzer wintzer
item.description:
@wintzer wrote:

Mr...x..:

check Server.cfg in your server file and make sure that you have the right port.

I think thats it!! It was on 5555 Lol Compiling now!

Read full topic
